SUMMARY: MhpR, hydroxyphenylpropionate regulator, participates in controlling expression of several genes involved in degradation of phenylpropionate (PP) [9098055, 12748194]. MhpR is able to bind to its DNA-binding site even in absence of inducer; however, increasing concentrations of inducer improve binding strength of MhpR. 3-(2,3-Dihydroxyphenyl)propionate (DHPP) and 3-hydroxyphenylpropionate (3HPP), two intermediates of metabolic pathways, are principal inducers of MhpR. third inducer, phenylpropionate (PP), acts synergistically with DHPP and 3HPP [12748194, 19520845]. This protein, which belongs to IclR family of transcriptional regulators, has a helix-turn-helix motif to bind DNA in its N-terminal domain and a 22-residue motif, specific to an IclR subfamily, in its C-terminal domain [9098055]. MhpR is necessary to recruit CRP to regulatory region of mhp operon, where both proteins activate transcription [12748194]. mhpR gene, which is located downstream of genes it regulates and in opposite direction, appears to be expressed constitutively [12748194].
